author: altair9732
content: hey guys, any idea on why some blocks after eip1559 have no txs, https://etherscan.io/block/12965030

author: mtshmtha
content: Are there any priority fee oracles? And is there a dashboard which shows the priority fee numbers for the past blocks?

author: altair9732
content: isn't that considered some sort of money laundering? eh

author: trent_vanepps
content: what? no

author: altair9732
content: i mean since there is no tx inside then why does he mine empty blocks, which i assume since there is no tx

author: trent_vanepps
content: there are a number of reasons, one of which being that the miner would rather propagate a small empty block and keep the block reward rather than fill it with tx and potentially get uncled (left on an abandoned fork)

author: timbeiko
content: also, IIRC, there is a quirk about when miners start mining a new block that means if they find a block quick it is likelier to be 100% empty than have, say, 1-10 txns

author: asn_d6
content: how does that quirk work? wouldn't they have already added a bunch of txs from the mempool even if the block was found quickly?

author: timbeiko
content: I'm not an expert, but AIUI, you can win a few ms by starting to build an empty block before adding txns to it, so if they find a block in that time, it's worth it to propagate it

author: asn_d6
content: ack. thanks!

author: altair9732
content: thanks for clarity

author: underbasic
content: there is a small cost to adding each transaction, therefore a zero tip transaction is likely to never be added to a block (or shouldn't in good economic theory)

author: underbasic
content: the marginal cost of adding a txn though is likely below 1 so anything over 1 should get added

author: underbasic
content: 1 or great that is

author: underbasic
content: I don't have the data to tell you what the marginal cost (eg the increased chance of an uncle) would be, but I am sure the big pools have some idea

author: cryptoinvestor9240
content:
Hello! Can anyone show me example: how to use gas price oracle(https://etherchain.org/api/gasPriceOracle for example) with web3.js call methods results to generate gas properties for pass it to estimate and send transaction methods?

I'm currently using only gasPrice property for transaction, which is legacy. And estimateGas method throwing "max fee per gas less than block base fee" error

content: Maybe I'm using the wrong channel for that question?

author: gregthegreek
content: Sorry I was afk

author: gregthegreek
content: It shouldn‚Äôt block you dapp unless your users wallet balance is really close to the base fee

author: gregthegreek
content: I can try running some numbers tomorrow if needed. But theoretically it would be like err = user_balance == baseFee+tip * 10% or something. Did some really quick napkin math on that one

author: gregthegreek
content: <@543900561460822016> did you ever run numbers on this or just patch it ?

author: gregthegreek
content: It actually might happen if you‚Äôre running a metatx but that should have happened before if they were paying with stables or similar

author: lightclient
content: <@322222239850168331> if the wallet has less than `block.gas_limit * to.maxFeePerGas + tx.value` it will fail

author: gregthegreek
content: And there it is folks

author: gregthegreek
content: Thanks üôè

author: gregthegreek
content: Use infura to estimate your gas price if you really need it right now

author: gregthegreek
content: Or a different client! Diversity is good
